important_phrase: Contacts also indicated that oil and gas inventories remained elevated despite increased demand
District firms continued to report difficulties filling a range of positions, and wage growth remained steady

In response to labor shortages and rising turnover, a growing number of firms indicated that they were directing resources towards creating internal training and development programs for both new hires and existing staff, covering technical education as well as company culture and soft skills
Lenders increased oversight of construction loans and were growing more cautious in multi-family lending
Rail activity, including intermodal, remained relatively flat
Most builders expect construction activity to hold steady at the current pace or increase slightly over the next three months
Sentiment among tourism and hospitality contacts across the District remains cautiously optimistic
Labor markets remained tight, and employers said wage increases were modest to moderate
Price changes remained modest
The outlook was generally positive but cautious
In greater Hartford, office leasing remained subdued as foot traffic slowed further
Retail contacts consulted in mid-May reported that year-over-year comparable-store sales ranged from low-single-digit declines to low-single-digit gains
Michigan fruit growers faced increased uncertainty after a major freeze potentially damaged their plants
Prices rose modestly
Prices again rose modestly overall in April and early May
Auto loan demand declined slightly
Shipping volumes increased slightly
Demand for nonresidential construction increased slightly, with improvements concentrated in the industrial sector
Consumer spending decreased slightly overall in April and early May
Manufacturing activity grew slightly, with a marked improvement for heavy equipment producers
Grocery store shelf prices declined slightly
Activity in mortgage lending expanded slightly, mainly for new purchases
Freight volume expanded during the period, and this expansion was attributed to improving economic conditions
Office vacancy rates declined, and asking rents increased, although both at a slow pace
Auto dealers are concerned about higher-than-normal inventories and credit tightening for subprime buyers
Moisture levels remained favorable across the district
Housing demand grew, lending activity increased, and the energy sector saw further improvement
Overall employment rose moderately, and upward wage pressures were similar to the last report
Lenders reported higher net interest margins and non-interest income, improved loan performance, and a slight tightening of credit standards on C&I and CRE loans
Demand for nonfinancial services expanded moderately over the past six weeks, and outlooks remained fairly optimistic
Apartment leasing activity in Houston was better than expected, and one contact noted that absorption (year to date through April) was slowly returning to a more normal pace
Retail sales rose at a slightly faster pace than the previous reporting period, and outlooks were positive
District energy activity expanded modestly compared to the prior survey period, and expectations remained positive
District energy activity also expanded modestly compared to the previous survey period, and bankers reported steady overall loan demand, stable deposit levels, and a slight decline loan quality
Respondents in the retail sector reported modestly higher input and selling prices, with both expected to rise moderately moving forward
Wile most bankers reported stable demand for commercial real estate loans, a relatively higher proportion than other types indicated increasing demand
Shipments, new orders, and order backlogs expanded slightly, and activity was modestly higher than a year ago
Inventories in residential housing were moderately below year-ago levels, but expectations were for a modest increase in the months ahead
Retail sales expanded slightly over the previous survey period and were moderately above year-ago levels
However, growing conditions have improved
Employment grew moderately, tempered by poor labor availability
Employment grew moderately since the last report, tempered by poor labor availability
Professional services activity was up modestly
Commercial real estate transactions also slowed slightly
Tourism conditions were mixed since the previous report
Most energy sectors tended to modestly improve
On balance, pricing pressures were little changed from the prior report, with most Districts reporting modest increases
Manufacturers indicated that business activity has flattened out, while service-sector contacts have continued to report steady to modestly expanding activity
Business contacts continued to note rising input costs but only modest increases in selling prices
Credit standards were reported to be unchanged across all loan categories
Businesses in most service industries noted little change in general business activity, while contacts in education & health services continued to indicate steady, moderate growth
New starts of single-family homes have remained subdued, while new multi-family construction has slowed substantially
Retailers reported that sales were steady to down moderately
Manufacturing and homebuilding continued at a moderate pace of growth, but nonfinancial services appear to have slowed to a modest pace
Price pressures appeared to ease a bit, although on balance, levels continued to rise modestly
Banking contacts continued to express cautious optimism for slow, steady growth
Most indicators, especially new orders, suggested slower growth; however, all were representative of a normal pace for the Third District
Homebuilders continued to report moderate increases in traffic and contract signings and expressed concerns that the labor supply will not support higher levels of construction activity
After a slower first quarter, several events lifted Philadelphia area hotel and restaurant activity to stronger levels
Energy markets improved modestly in recent weeks
Prices were reportedly stable to rising moderately
Prices were generally stable to rising modestly
Business lending increased modestly
Expectations for the next six months were generally optimistic, with firms anticipating moderate increases in new orders and shipments
Residential real estate sales increased moderately since the previous report
An adventure camp facility in western Virginia reported that bookings increased at a better-than-seasonal pace from March to April
Demand from canneries for tomatoes softened, and the number of new tomato plantings is expected to decline
The labor market tightened further, while upward wage pressures grew moderately overall
Electricity prices expanded at a moderate pace
Demand for automobile loans slowed
In the aerospace and defense industry, capacity utilization improved modestly
Residential construction activity remained strong in urban centers but slowed to a moderate pace in some rural regions, due in part to especially wet ground conditions in areas of the Mountain Wst
Overall, retail sales expanded at a modest pace
Natural resource extraction conditions improved modestly from the previous report and year
District labor market conditions continue to improve, with modest employment growth and moderate growth in wages
House prices increased moderately
Banking conditions continued to strengthen at a moderate pace, driven primarily by strong growth in demand for business and mortgage loans
Despite the optimistic outlook, some contacts expressed concerns about regulatory uncertainty and the difficulty of finding employees
Residential construction improved modestly since the previous report
Hospitality contacts in St Louis and Louisville indicated a modest increase in business activity after a slow first quarter
